comments: a(n) is the number of positive divisors of n of the form 3k+1. If r(n) denotes the number of representations of n by the quadratic form j^2+ij+i^2, then r(n)= 6 *(a(n)-A001822(n)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jun 24 2002a(n) = (A035191(n) + A002324(n)) / 2. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 26 2011
references: B. C. Berndt,"On a certain theta-function in a letter of Ramanujan from Fitzroy House", Ganita 43 (1992),33-43.
links: Nick Hobson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
P. G. Dirichlet, Recherches sur diverses applications de l'analyse infinitesimale a la theorie des nombres, J. Reine Angew. Math. 21 (1840), 1-12.
Michael Gilleland, Some Self-Similar Integer Sequences
formula: Moebius transform is period 3 sequence [1, 0, 0, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Sep 20 2005G.f.: Sum_{k>0} x^(3k-2)/(1-x^(3k-2)) = Sum_{k>0} x^k/(1-x^(3k)). - _Michael Somos_, Sep 20 2005Equals A051731 * [1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 1,...], where A051731 is the inverse Mobius transform. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 06 2007
mathematica: a[n_] := DivisorSum[n, Boole[Mod[#, 3] == 1]&]; Array[a, 100] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Dec 01 2015 *)
prog: (PARI) a(n)=if(n<1,0,sumdiv(n,d,d%3==1))(Haskell)a001817 n = length [d | d <- [1,4..n], mod n d == 0]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 26 2011
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
